title: The Teachings and Influence of Lord Buddha | HH Stoka Krishna Swami
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Lord Buddha is a powerful incarnation of the personality of Godhead.
segments.summary: This segment introduces Lord Buddha as an empowered incarnation of Godhead, predicted to appear in Gaya, Bihar.
segments.transcript: Tathaskalau sampravrttye sammohaya suradvisham buddho namna anjana sutaha kikateshu bhavishyati. Suta Goswami is speaking in the future tense. Bhavishyati means will appear in the future. Lord Buddha is a powerful incarnation of the personality of Godhead. Buddha is an empowered incarnation, shaktiavesha avatara. Of course, for us now, Buddha appeared in the past because 5000 years have elapsed since Kali Yuga began. So Buddha came about 2500 years back. He appeared in the province of Gaya, Bihar as a son of Anjana.

segments.key_quote: Lord Buddha preached non-violence, taking pity on the poor animals.
segments.summary: This segment describes the atheistic environment at the time of Buddha's appearance, characterized by excessive animal sacrifice, and highlights Buddha's preaching of non-violence.
segments.transcript: At the time when Lord Buddha appeared, the people in general were atheistic and preferred animosity. They preferred animosity over the animal flesh. On the plea of Vedic sacrifice, every place was practically turned into a slaughterhouse, and animal killing was indulged in unrestrictedly. Lord Buddha preached non-violence, taking pity on the poor animals.

segments.key_quote: When the Vedas are not accepted through the authoritative disciplic succession, the casual readers of the Vedas are misled by the flowery language of that system of knowledge.
segments.summary: This segment explains the Vedic perspective on animal sacrifice, emphasizing the importance of understanding the Vedas through disciplic succession and the concept of reviving the sacrificed animal.
segments.transcript: He preached that he did not believe in the tenets of the Vedas, and stressed the adverse psychological effect of non-violence incurred by animal killing. When the Vedas are not accepted through the authoritative disciplic succession, the casual readers of the Vedas are misled by the flowery language of that system of knowledge. They have no depth of knowledge. Now, animal killing is specifically allowed in the Vedic sacrifices to test the power of the mantra being chanted by a particular Brahman. What is done is an old cow or an old bull is offered in sacrifice, but after that sacrifice the animal is revived. The soul in the animal's body is getting a new body.

segments.key_quote: Lord Buddha deluded the atheists because such atheists who followed his principle did not believe in God but they kept their absolute faith in Lord Buddha who himself was the incarnation of God.
segments.summary: This segment explains how Lord Buddha trained atheists in moral discipline and non-violence, leading them towards God realization by instilling faith in him as an incarnation of God.
segments.transcript: Less intelligent men of the age of Kali who had no faith in God followed the principle of Lord Buddha, and for the time being they were trained in moral discipline and non-violence, the preliminary steps for proceeding further on the path of God realization. Lord Buddha deluded the atheists because such atheists who followed his principle did not believe in God, but they kept their absolute faith in Lord Buddha who himself was the incarnation of God.

segments.key_quote: He made the faithless faithful to him.
segments.summary: This segment explains that the purpose of the Vedas is to lead one to the Supreme Lord and how Lord Buddha made faithless people believe in God in the form of Lord Buddha.
segments.transcript: According to the Bhagavad Gita, Vedascha Sarvair Ahameva Vedyah. The whole system of the Vedas is to lead one gradually to the path of the Supreme Lord, to know the Supreme Lord, the individual soul, the cosmic situation, and the relation between all these items. When the relation is known, the relative function begins. Thus the faithless people were made to believe in God in the form of Lord Buddha. That was the mercy of Lord Buddha. He made the faithless faithful to him.
